metadata.title: Synthesis of bio-inspired N-doped SiC and investigation of its synergetic effects on Mo catalysts in oxidative desulfurization reaction

Fig. 1 FT-IR spectra of SiC-GG and SiC/Mo composites. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 Raman spectra of SiC-GG and SiC/Mo composites. Fig. 2 Fig. 3 Powder XRD diffraction patterns of SiC-GG and GG/Mo composites. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 SEM images of SiC-GG (a) and GG/Mo4 composite (b). Fig. 4 Fig. 5 EDX elemental mapping of GG/Mo4 composite. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of SiC-GG (a) and GG/Mo4 composite (b), and differential and cumulative pore volume distribution of SiC-GG (c) and GG/Mo4 composite (d) using NLDFT model. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 Effect of reaction temperature on oxidation of DBT with synthesized catalysts at optimized condition: 5mg catalyst, 2ml of model fuel 100 ppm(S), 1ml hydrogen peroxide (30%), 1ml CH3CN. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 Effect of amount of catalyst on oxidation of DBT at optimized condition: 2ml of model fuel 100 ppm(S), 1μl hydrogen peroxide (30%), 1ml CH3CN, 60°C. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 Effect of amount of oxidant on oxidation of DBT at optimized condition: 5mg catalyst, 2ml of model fuel 100 ppm(S), 1ml CH3CN, 60°C. Fig. 9 Fig. 10 Effect of reagent concentration on oxidation of DBT at optimized condition: 5mg catalyst, 2ml of model fuel, 1μl hydrogen peroxide (30%), 1ml CH3CN, 60°C. Fig. 10 Fig. 11 Oxidation of model fuel of BT, DBT, and 4,6DMDBT (1:1:1) at optimized condition: 5mg catalyst, 2ml of model fuel 500 ppm(S), 1μl hydrogen peroxide (30%), 1ml CH3CN, 60°C. Fig. 11 Fig. 12 Comparison of catalytic activities of N-doped SiC/Mo catalyst with SiC/Mo and N-doped C/Mo catalysts and their supports without metal. Fig. 12 Fig. 13 FTIR characterization of fresh, used, and washed catalysts. Fig. 13 Table 1 Elemental percentage of SiC-GG and its Mo composites. Graphical abstract Bio-inspired N-doped silicon carbide/Mo composites have been successfully synthesized through a facile method, combining magnesiothermic synthesis of biomorphic N-doped SiC by using gelatin biopolymer and embedded molybdenum composites forming in situ. The resulting composite materials contain MoO2, Mo2C, and MoSi2 particles dispersed well on N-doped SiC matrix. The composites displayed superior catalytic properties in oxidative desulfurization of model fuel (99.6%). The comparison between catalytic activity of N-doped SiC, N-doped carbon and SiC without nitrogen dopants demonstrated that N-doped SiC composites are more promising for ODS reaction. Comparable catalytic activity, higher durability, and lower reaction time are the advantages make this composite a good ODS catalysts and a green and cost-effective alternative for practical desulfurization of fuel. Keywords N-doped silicon carbide Molybdenum carbide Composite Oxidative desulfurization 1 Introduction The removal of sulfur compounds in fuel is an important environmental concern [1–3]. Toxic sulfur compounds are released to the atmosphere and cause significant environmental and health problems [4,5]. Currently, hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process is widely used to reduce the sulfur content in the commercial fuels. However, HDS is cost-intensive process and less effective to remove thiophenic compounds [6]. Therefore, research is carried out to propose alternative technologies to obtain low-sulfur fuels. Among them, oxidative desulfurization (ODS) is considered as a promising approach because of its low-energy consumption [7,8]. In this method, thiophenic compounds are converted to related sulfones under mild condition which can be easily removed by adsorption or extraction [9,10]. The best results were achieved when transition metal oxides are used as catalysts; such as Mo, W, V, Ti, etc. [11–14]. Among them, MoO3-based (Mo(VI)) catalyst has been widely used in ODS reaction, but little research has been reported on MoO2-based (Mo(IV)) catalyst[15]. MoO2 has been used as a catalyst for oxidation, alkane isomerization, metathesis, or reforming reactions [16–20]. MoO2 has high density in the valence band energy than can enhance the catalytic activity [21–23]. Also, molybdenum carbide has been reported to show excellent catalytic properties in dry-methane reforming, steam-methane reforming, partial oxidation of methane, and oxidative dehydrogenation [24,25]. But only few reports focused on using Mo2C on ODS reaction [26]. Furthermore, alumina [27,28], silica [29] and activated carbon [30] are intensely used as catalyst supports in oxidation reactions of organosulfur compounds. However, silicon carbide, has never been employed as a catalyst in the ODS process. Besides the structural stabilization of the molybdenum carbide and oxide nanoparticles, the intrinsic structure and defect of the SiC support will also effect on product properties. Silicon carbide has attracted attention due to its semiconducting properties, high mechanical strength, high thermal conductivity, good chemical inertness and excellent thermal shock resistance [31,32]. Thus, it widely has been used in electronic and optical devices, drug delivery, hydrogen storage, and catalyst support [33–35]. Silicon carbide can be synthesized by various methods [36,37]. The main disadvantages of these methods include high synthesis temperature, and expensive and not environmentally-friendly raw material precursors [38]. Addition, all the existing methods are unable to control the structure of the product [39]. Magnesiothermic reduction is a novel method, which synthesizes nanostructures at temperatures much lower than what was previously has been produced [39,40]. In general, for controlling structural properties of materials, including external shape, internal porosity and surface area, surfactants or polymers have been used as template [41]. But, most of polymers and surfactants used as templates are expensive and most often toxic and not suitable for ecosystems [42,43]. These problems are surmountable using renewable natural materials as templates [44]. Natural biopolymers are nontoxic, biocompatible and biodegradable materials that can be selected here as good candidates for carbon template. Moreover they are an infinite source in nature and inexpensive materials. In this work, we employed bio-inspired approaches for the preparation of N-doped SiC foam containing MoO2/Mo2C/MoSi2 nanocomposites (designated as SiC-Mo). Gelatin as a natural material containing N species (a heterogeneous mixture of proteins) was selected as a suitable carbon source for synthesis of self-assembly N-doped silicon carbide. Also, sodium molybdate was used as molybdenum precursor. Furthermore, we evaluate the catalytic properties of the as-synthesized N-doped SiC-MoO2/Mo2C/MoSi2 composites as oxidative desulfurization catalysts to obtain low sulfur fuel. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods All chemicals and solvents used in the syntheses were reagent grade and used without further purification. Commercial gelatin was obtained from Merck chemical company. Magnesium powder (0.3–0.06μm), Tetraethyl orthosilicate, ethanol, hydrochloric acid (37%) and hydrofluoric acid (40%) used for synthesis of SiC matrix. Dibenzothiophene (DBT), benzothiophene (BT), 4,6dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6DMDBT), n-octane, hydrogen peroxide and molybdenum oxide were obtained from Merck. n-Dodecane was used as internal standard for the quantitative analysis of the product using gas choromatography and acetonitrile that was used as extractive solvent were also obtained from Merck. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) images were obtained on TESCAN, VEGA3. Crystalline phases were identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD) using filtered CuKα radiation (λ=1.54060Å) in the range 2θ=5–80° (BrukerAxs, D8 Advance). Infrared spectra were measured on a Bruker, Vector spectrometer. Adsorption and desorption isotherms and were recorded by Belsorp mini instrument. Raman spectra were obtained with Bruker, Senterra micro-Raman with a laser wavelength of 785nm. Catalytic tests were taken with GC-FID (Faraz Gostar, TG 2552). 2.2 Preparation of precursors Sol-gel method was used for preparation of precursors. 5g of gelatin was dispersed in 40ml water under vigorous mixing. The mixture was then placed in boiling water bath with vigorous stirring for 2h. After cooling down to room temperature, the gels were used as N-doped carbon precursor. For synthesis of SiC/Mo composites, the prepared gelatin gel mixed with different amount of molybdenum salt (sodium molybdate): 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 1.25g. Then the composites were sonicated for 15min (120W) and used as N-doped carbon/molybdenum precursors. The silica precursor was prepared using tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) according to previous literatures. TEOS, ethanol and water were mixed together at 8: 4: 5.5 ratios under mild stirring for 1h. After homogenization of the mixture, it was used as silica precursor for synthesizing the silicon carbide nanostructures. 2.3 Synthesis of N-doped silicon carbide Porous N-doped SiC was synthesized by mixing carbon and silica precursors. After homogenization of the mixture with ultrasonic agitation, acetic acid solution was added by dropwise until the resulting sol had a pH in the range of 4–5. The mixture was then put in a drying oven, treated at 80°C for 12h. The dried mixture was carbonized at 750°C for 1h under argon atmosphere to form SiO2/C composites. After that, the SiO2/C composites were mixed with magnesium powder (SiO2: Mg molar ratio of 1:2) and put in a ceramic crucible, heated in an electrical furnace to 750°C for 6h with heating rate of 5°C/min in Ar. Finally, the mesoporous N-doped SiC was obtained after cooling to room temperature. To remove magnesia (MgO), the resulting powders were immersed in a 2M HCl solution for 24h at room temperature. Finally, the samples were exposed to a HF solution to remove any unreacted silica for 24h. At last, the samples were washed with ethanol and water, and dried at 40°C for 4h in a vacuum oven. Bio-inspired N-doped SiC was coded with GG. 2.4 Synthesis of SiC/Mo composites For synthesis of SiC/Mo composites, the above procedures repeated for carbon/molybdenum precursors and silica gel. The obtained SiC composites were named as GG/Mo1, GG/Mo2, GG/Mo3, and GG/Mo4 corresponding to the 0.5, 0.75, 1, and 1.25g of molybdenum salt, respectively. 2.5 Catalytic test DBT was dissolved in n-octane to prepare model fuel solutions with 100, 250 and 500ppm total sulfur. The catalytic experiments were carried out in a 25ml flask, equipped with a magnetic stirrer at an atmospheric pressure and different constant temperature (25–60°C). In a typical catalytic process, 2ml of model fuel, 2.5–7.5mg of catalyst, 1ml acetonitrile as extractive solvent and dodecane as internal standard was added to a reactor and stirred for 5min. Then 0.5–1.5μl of H2O2 was introduced. In each 10-min period, the oil phase was withdrawn and determined by GC to investigate the conversion percent of DBT. Also another model fuel with the mixture of BT, DBT and 4,6DMDBT (equal amount of each sulfur compounds with total sulfur of 500ppm) was tested to evaluate the selectivity of catalysts. 3 Results and discussion A bio-inspired approach was use for the synthesis of N-doped SiC foam embedded by MoO2/Mo2C/MoSi2 composites. The gelatin has been selected as a carbon source with nitrogen species that has self-assembling capability to produce N-doped carbon skeleton [45–47]. The XPS analysis of prepared N-doped carbon has shown the presence of four types of N-containing groups: pyridine, pyrrole, graphite, and pyridine-N-oxide nitrogen species. Among them, the pyridinic and pyrrolic nitrogen contribute is predominant in the N-doped carbon product [47]. Using magnesiothermic method for synthesis of SiC helps us to achieve the nanoporous structure. In the presence of metal precursor, there are molecular interactions between the amine groups in gelatin matrix and molybdenum ions. So, it can result the homogenous distribution of the molybdenum precursor in the gelatin matrix. At high temperature, molybdenum precursor converted to MoO2 and in the presence of carbon and Si, Mo2C and MoSi2 can achieve too. 3.1 Characterization In order to study the surface characteristics of Si/Mo composites, FTIR analysis was carried out. FTIR spectra for N-doped SiC and four SiC/Mo composites are presented in Fig. 1 . Corresponding peak to the Si-C bonds were observed in about 813–837cm−1 for GG and its composites. The shoulder appeared in about 913–914cm−1 are assigned to Mo-O stretching vibration in SiC/Mo composites. As Fig. 1 shows, there were small differences in Si-C bonds in GG-SiC and its composites due to molybdenum grafting. Fig. 2 shows the Raman scattering analysis of prepared SiC and its composites. The Raman spectra reveal two characteristic bands, namely the D band at about 1310cm−1, and G band at 1578cm −1. These bands are related to graphene structures. The presence of these bands can be indicated the forming of SiC siligraphene structure [48]. The SiC siligraphene (SiCx) can be another form of Si doped graphene [49,50]. These bands are sharper in SiC siligraphene than the bands in graphene. The ratio of G band to D band intensities (ID/IG) is estimated to be 1.12 for SiC-GG that is less than its composites: GG/Mo1 (1.24), GG/Mo2 (1.33), GG/Mo3 (1.37), and GG/Mo4 (1.42). This trend of the ID/IG ratio was approved the more defects in the structure of composits due to grafting of Mo structures in SiC matrix. In order to identify the crystal structure of SiC and its composite, XRD analysis was performed. Fig. 3 shows the XRD patterns of prepared N-doped SiC (GG) and its composites (GG/Mo1-4). The XRD analysis of GG confirmed the presence of hexagonal SiC (6H-SiC) and a little amount of Si. In Fig. 3a, the diffraction peaks at 34.5, 35.58, 38.9, 40.8, 59.08, 65.07, and 72.01° can be indexed as the (101), (102), (103), (104), (110), and (109) reflections of 6H hexagonal structure of SiC (JCPDS#29-1128). In the XRD patterns of the prepared SiC composite (GG/Mo), there are some additional peaks matches well with MoO2 (JCPDS#65-1273), Mo2C (JCPDS#31-0871), and MoSi2 (JCDPS#41-0612) structures. The diffraction peaks located at 26.14, 38.62, 55.78, and 62.62° are ascribed to the (011), (020), (022), and (031) reflections of the monoclinic MoO2 structure, while the diffraction peaks at 33.7, 39.76, 41.38, 48.34, 66.28, and 75.52° are indexed as the (021), (200), (121), (221), (040), and (240) reflections of orthorhombic Mo2C structure. MoSi2 was produced during siliconization process. The diffraction peaks at 22.66, 30.04, 44.74, 46.18, and 75.22° are indexed as the (002), (101), (103), (112), and (220) reflections of MoSi2 structure. SEM micrographs of prepared N-doped SiC and its composite are presented in Fig. 4 . It was deduced that the gelatin as carbon skeleton in SiC matrix plays a template role during carbonization process. By adding molybdenum precursor in the silicon carbide matrix, the morphology of composite is varied and larger pore appeared. In order to analysis the composition of N-doped SiC composite accurately, EDX-SEM mapping technique was used (Fig. 5 ). EDX elemental mapping shows the well-dispersity of Mo and N in the matrix of SiC. This result shows that this strategy is effective in yielding good dispersion of the catalyst in composite and can be effective to achieve better catalytic properties. It is worth noting that according the EDX analysis, the N elements in composites were reduced by increasing the Mo content; 3.77, 3.67, 3.62, 3.61, and 2.6% in GG, GG/Mo1, GG/Mo2, GG/Mo3 and, GG/Mo4, respectively (Table 1 ). The amount of Mo in the composites are calculated 4.03, 8.51, 12.4, and 17.33% in GG/Mo1, GG/Mo2, GG/Mo3 and, GG/Mo4, respectively (Table 1). The mesoporosity of the N–doped SiC (GG) and its composite (GG/Mo) were studied by N2 adsorption-desorption measurements (Table 2 ). As Fig. 6 shows, the prepared SiC products exhibit representative type-IV curves with H3 hysteresis loop, which are characteristic of mesoporous materials with open-slit shape pores. The specific BET surface areas were calculated for GG, GG/Mo1, GG/Mo2, GG/Mo3, and GG/Mo4 composite, 202, 203, 201, 200, and 201m2/g, respectively. The pore size distribution data was determined by NLDFT method indicates the present of larger pores in the GG/Mo composite (Fig. 6). As shown in Table 2, the average pore volume of GG (9.47nm) are significantly increased in GG/Mo composites (12.98, 13.47, 14.67, and 16.91nm for GG/Mo1, GG/Mo2, GG/Mo3, and GG/Mo4, respectively) without decreasing the surface area. 3.2 Catalytic study The catalytic activities of synthesized composites (GG/Mo1-4) were tested in oxidative desulfurization of model fuel. The reaction conditions were optimized for the maximum oxidation by different parameters, such as the reaction temperature, amount of catalyst and oxidant, and concentration of DBT (Table 3 ). Also the mixed of thiophenic derivatives was tested as a model fuel to investigate the selectivity of catalysts. The reaction was performed in acetonitrile as an extractive solvent in double phase oxidation reaction of DBT. Fig. 7 shows the results of oxidation of DBT over four synthesized catalysts at different temperatures. Reaction temperature is a key factor in the catalytic ODS process. DBT removal and the rate of reaction enhanced with the increase of temperature. The best conversion results obtained at 60°C by using GG/Mo4 catalyst (99.6% after 60min). While, the oxidation at 40°C reached to an acceptable value (99.5%) after a lower time (160min). Also, results show that the rate of reaction is very low at room temperature and the conversion reaches to 87% after 180min. Fig. 7 shows that by increasing the amount of active site (Mo loading%) in the catalyst, higher elimination of sulfur observed. In summary, the activity of catalysts for the oxidation of DBT diminished in the order: GG/Mo4>GG/Mo3>GG/Mo2>GG/Mo1 (99.6>98>93.4>82% for 17.33, 12.4, 8.51, and 4.03 Mo loading%, respectively). To determine the influence of amount of catalyst on the oxidation of DBT, the reactions carried out by using various amount of catalyst (Fig. 8 ). Conversion increased clearly with an increase in the amount of catalyst from 2.5 to 5mg, further increase only increases the rate of reaction. Fig. 9 shows the effect of amount of oxidant (H2O2). With the increase in the molar ratio of O/S, the reaction rate increased and maximized at 99.7% at the O/S ratio of 3. The conversion is low in the lower amount of oxidant and increased by increasing H2O2 up to 1μl. The influence of reagent concentration also was evaluated in this heterogeneous system. As shown in Fig. 10 , by increasing the concentration of reagent, conversion decreased slowly, and the highest activity (99.6%) and rate of reaction (60min) obtained when the reagent with 100 ppm(S) is used. Also, the oxidation of another model fuel containing three thiophene derivatives (BT, DBT, and 4,6DMDBT) was performed under optimal condition to evaluate the selectivity of catalysts (Fig. 11 ). Based on the catalytic data, the 99.6, 91, and 52% selectivity were achieved for oxidation of DBT, 4,6DMDBT, and BT by using GG/Mo4 catalyst. These results can be described by two factors: the electron density of S atom and the steric hindrance of thiophenic derivatives. The reactivity of sulfur compound is increased by increasing the electron density of S atom. So, the oxidation of BT is most difficult due to its lower electron density. In reverse, DBT was oxidized easier than 4,6-DMDBT, because of higher steric-hindrance of methyl substitutions of 4,6-DMDBT. To determine the effect of N-doped SiC support on the catalytic activity of synthesized catalyst, the results were compared with N-doped carbon support and SiC without nitrogen dopants (Fig. 12 ). Results show that the incorporation of the heteroatoms (N, Si) into a graphene structure can enhance the catalytic activity by modifying the surface and electronic properties of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 12, the conversion of N-SiC/Mo catalyst reaches to 99.6% after 40min, while in NC/Mo catalyst, the 99.5% conversion obtained after 180min. This result can be justified by the structure of silicon carbide. According to the mechanism, increasing the electron density of peroxo groups on the active catalyst (Mo(OO)) can increase the catalytic activity by decreasing the σ*(OO) (LUMO) level. A lower energy of the LUMO orbital, decreases the gap between the HOMO-LUMO and decrease the oxidation barrier accordingly. In silicon carbide structure, by replacing the Si atom instead of C in the graphene structure, the electron density on the peroxo groups can increase, so the oxidation barrier is decreased. It can be observed in the better catalytic performance of SiC than carbon-based catalyst. Also, the comparison between N-SiC/Mo catalyst with SiC/Mo shows that doping with nitrogen has a good impression on the catalytic activity. It seems that N-atom can activate the peroxo center, so better oxygen transfer reaction occurred. Also in Fig. 12, the catalytic activities of metal composites were compared with their supports. Results show that metal-free supports can also oxidize the sulfur compounds via radical generation that is activated by charge transfer from positively charge sites to chemisorbed oxidant in N-doped Structures [51]. In N-doped carbon structure, the positively charged carbons are the active sites that can facilitate the adsorption of oxidant and dissociate the OO bond of oxidant [52]. According to the previous literatures, we supposed that oxidant molecule can also be absorbed on SiC siligraphene structure by bonding with two adjacent silicon atoms. When O was adsorbed on the Si sites, the charge transfer from SiC to O can lead to dissociate the OO bond and activate the oxidation process [53]. The synergistic effect of Si and N doping can effectively change the inertness of graphene system to facilitate the electron transfer and activate the radical generation. So, the best sulfur removal was observed in the N-doped SiC support due to the more charge transfer of catalyst. It can be concluded that N-doped SiC is attractive candidate as metal-free catalyst and can also enhance the catalytic properties of Mo nanocatalysts by modifying the electronic structure via electron transfer to metal center. To demonstrate the reusability of catalysts, we undertake the recovery experiment by performing a series of consecutive experiments in which the used catalyst was filtered, washed several times with fresh solvent (under ultrasonic), and employed without any further treatment in another run. The results have been shown clearly that no loss of activity occurs after five cycles of reuse. To verify this observation, the fresh, used, and washed catalysts were characterized by FTIR analysis (Fig. 13 ). After the catalytic reaction, more peaks are appeared in the FTIR spectra of used catalyst. The peaks at 1288 and 1166cm−1 are assigned to the stretching mode of SO2 group in dibenzothiophene sulfone, the product of ODS process. When the used catalyst was regenerated by washing to remove the product that is absorbed on the surface of catalyst, the FTIR spectrum of the washed catalyst shows the same spectrum as the fresh one and no SO2 vibrations was observed. 4 Conclusion We developed here a simple bioinspired synthesis approach which leads to in situ N-doped SiC composites with MoO2/Mo2C/MoSi2 nanoparticles embedded uniformly in the SiC matrix. Gelatin provides the N-doped carbon skeleton that is reacted with TEOS to synthesis of N-doped silicon carbide. In the presence of molybdenum precursor, molecular interactions between the amine groups in gelatin matrix and molybdenum ions, resulting the homogenous distribution of the molybdenum in the SiC matrix. As applied as the oxidative desulfurization catalysts, the as-prepared SiC/Mo composites exhibit excellent activity. The superior catalytic activity could be attributed to the synergistic combination of MoO2/Mo2C/MoSi2, presented within a conductive N-doped SiC matrix. The comparison between catalytic activity of N-doped SiC support with N-doped carbon and SiC without nitrogen dopants demonstrated that N-doped SiC composites are more promising for ODS reaction. In silicon carbide structure, by replacing the Si atom instead of C in the graphene structure, the electron density on the peroxo groups can increase, so the oxidation barrier is decreased. Also, it seems that N-atom can activate the peroxo center, so better oxygen transfer reaction occurred. coredata.dc:description: Bio-inspired N-doped silicon carbide/Mo composites have been successfully synthesized through a facile method, combining magnesiothermic synthesis of biomorphic N-doped SiC by using gelatin biopolymer and embedded molybdenum composites forming in situ. The resulting composite materials contain MoO2, Mo2C, and MoSi2 particles dispersed well on N-doped SiC matrix. The composites displayed superior catalytic properties in oxidative desulfurization of model fuel (99.6%). The comparison between catalytic activity of N-doped SiC, N-doped carbon and SiC without nitrogen dopants demonstrated that N-doped SiC composites are more promising for ODS reaction. Comparable catalytic activity, higher durability, and lower reaction time are the advantages make this composite a good ODS catalysts and a green and cost-effective alternative for practical desulfurization of fuel.
coredata.dc:title: Synthesis of bio-inspired N-doped SiC and investigation of its synergetic effects on Mo catalysts in oxidative desulfurization reaction
